summary: This is a 2019 New York Times article reporting on Jeffrey Epstein's arrest on federal sex trafficking charges in Manhattan. It details the discovery of lewd photographs in his mansion, criticizes the 2008 plea deal overseen by Alexander Acosta, and outlines the new indictment alleging abuse of dozens of girls from 2002-2005. The article includes reactions from prosecutors, Epstein's lawyer, politicians, and accusers.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Charged with sex trafficking and conspiracy for allegedly abusing dozens of underage girls at his New York and Florida properties between 2002 and 2005. His 2008 plea deal is criticized.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney in Miami, then U.S. Labor Secretary
persons.context: Oversaw the 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein that shielded him from federal charges. Faced calls to resign in 2019.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Unsealed the 2019 indictment against Epstein, stated his office was not bound by the 2008 Florida deal, and encouraged other victims to come forward.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Argued the 2019 charges were a "do-over" of allegations already settled by the 2008 plea agreement and claimed the deal was approved at a high level in the DOJ.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.context: Recused himself from the Epstein case because his former law firm, Kirkland & Ellis, had represented Epstein.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Called for Alexander Acosta's resignation over the "unconscionable" 2008 agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Acknowledged taking four trips on Epstein's airplane and having past social visits, but stated he knew nothing about Epstein's crimes.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as part of Epstein's social circle of the rich and famous.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Was quoted from a 2002 magazine article describing Epstein as "a terrific guy" who liked "beautiful women... many of them on the younger side."

persons.name: Alexander Rossmiller
persons.context: Argued against bail for Epstein, citing his wealth as a flight risk and the discovery of nude photos as evidence of a continued predatory attitude.

persons.name: Eric Holland
persons.role: Deputy Assistant Secretary of Labor for Public Affairs
persons.context: Stated that Alexander Acosta had no comment on the 2019 developments.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Read a statement outside court from a client who said she was forced to have sex with Epstein in her 20s.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Was present in court with two women who said they were abused by Epstein as teenagers.

persons.name: William F. Sweeney Jr.
persons.role: Assistant Director in charge of the FBI's New York office
persons.context: Commented that adults often "turned a blind eye" to the type of criminal behavior Epstein was accused of.

persons.name: Ali Watkins
persons.context: Author of the New York Times article.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest and Search of Mansion
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey. Simultaneously, a search of his Manhattan mansion uncovered a trove of lewd photographs of nude/partially nude young women and girls in a locked safe.

events.title: Epstein Indictment Unsealed
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman unsealed a federal indictment charging Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy for alleged abuse of dozens of girls from 2002-2005 in New York and Florida.

events.title: Epstein's Court Appearance
events.description: Epstein, in a navy blue jumpsuit, pleaded not guilty to the charges in a packed Manhattan courtroom. Prosecutors argued against bail, citing his wealth and the discovered photos.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Federal prosecutors in Miami, led by Alexander Acosta, reached a secret plea deal with Epstein. It granted him federal immunity, required a state guilty plea to prostitution charges, 13 months in jail, and sex offender registration.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Scheme
events.description: The indictment alleges Epstein and his employees engaged in a scheme to bring dozens of girls, some as young as 14, to his NY and FL properties for sexual abuse during massages, paying them cash and incentivizing them to recruit others.

events.title: DOJ Internal Review Opened
events.description: The Justice Department opened an internal review into its handling of the 2008 Epstein case.

events.title: Florida Investigation Begins
events.description: Law enforcement in Florida began investigating Epstein after parents of an accuser filed a police report. State prosecutors prepared a 53-page indictment that was later shelved.

locations: Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan mansion/townhouse (Upper East Side, East 71st Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues)
Southern District of New York (federal court jurisdiction)
Southern District of Florida (federal court jurisdiction for 2008 deal)
keyFacts: Hundreds or thousands of 'sexually suggestive' photographs of nude or partially nude young women and girls were discovered in a locked safe in Epstein's Manhattan mansion during his arrest in July 2019.

The 2019 indictment alleges Epstein operated a sex-trafficking scheme from 2002-2005, abusing dozens of girls as young as 14 at his New York and Florida properties, and paying them to recruit other victims.

The 2008 non-prosecution agreement, overseen by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, granted Epstein federal immunity, was kept secret from victims, and allowed him to plead guilty to lesser state charges, avoiding a possible life sentence.
U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman explicitly stated the 2008 deal only bound the Southern District of Florida, allowing his office in New York to pursue new federal charges.
Following Epstein's arrest, several new accusers contacted prosecutors, including some who had never previously spoken to the government.
